messages.message:
@lenny do we already have a timeline for which release we are planning to move to 3.9?
I don’t expect many troubles with that on the ibformers side. An additional challenge compared with platform code will be that we would need to maintain backward compatibility i.e. ibformers would need to be tested both with python 3.9 and python 3.7 for some time.
the switch will be happening in 23.01, we are testing the change now and will be making the switch hopefully in the next week or two
Exciting! To confirm, will this also affect the Python version in `celery-app-tasks` - e.g for running Refiner functions/UDFs?

correct, the python version running UDFs will be updated as well. additionally there will be some package version upgrades made as well, to get everything compatible with py39 and to get package versions in sync across our platform

I assume this will impact python package versions running on Instabase as well? this will likely impact existing code behavior (in dev exchange packages developed on older version of Instabase for example). we should probably plan to have dev exchange packages which are widely used on Instabase tested with these new dependencies before these upgrades.

Another point. We would need to ensure as well that model solutions already trained with previous releases would still work in python 3.9 - otherwise, we would need to communicate to users to migrate all the solutions to the new version of python
@Vishnu that’s right. do you know if there are existing tests for dev exchange packages that i can leverage? what would be the best way to test these?
@Rafal good point. can i sync with you next week to talk through this?

some of our packages have unit tests which we run in our CI pipelines. we can probably try to replicate the instabase env dependencies and run the unit tests there to begin with. ib_validations has unit tests configured but no regression tests. I can link in with some of the other dev exchange package owners to get a list of the most used packages and their current level of testing.

that would be super helpful, ty! we’re already planning to run all of the unit tests, goldens, and system tests that are in the main instabase repo to validate the upgrade, and will flag any failures that come up there. if there are additional tests that aren’t part of that, or if there are some packages that we know require manual testing, we can make sure to run those as well.
Yes @Vishnu’s points were definitely my concern - `python3.7` -> `python3.9` itself should be okay but testing library changes will be key
